searchDocs.title: LogLevel​
searchDocs.content: </> type LogLevel = "info" | "warn" | "error" Log level types for the Log function.

searchDocs.title: Log​
searchDocs.content: </> Utils.Log( owner: string, reason: string, level: LogLevel? ) → () Logs a message with a specified owner and level. The log message is formatted as [owner]reason and output based on the level: "info": Uses print() "warn": Uses warn() "error": Uses error() local Utils = require(path.to.Utils) Utils.Log("MyService", "Initialization complete", "info") Utils.Log("MyComponent", "Warning message", "warn") Utils.Log("MyService", "Critical error", "error")

searchDocs.title: ServiceDef​
searchDocs.content: </> type ServiceDef = { Name: string, LoadOrder: number? } Configuration table for creating a new service.

searchDocs.title: ServiceData​
searchDocs.content: </> type ServiceData = ServiceDef & {} Internal data structure for service instances. onInit: ((self: Service) -> ())?; onStart: ((self: Service) -> ())?; }

searchDocs.title: new​
searchDocs.content: </> Service:new(options: ServiceDef) → Service Creates a new service definition. This is typically called by Crane:CreateService. local service = Service.new({ Name = "MyService", LoadOrder = 1, })

searchDocs.title: Init​
searchDocs.content: </> Service:Init() → () Initializes the service by calling the onInit callback if it exists. This method is automatically called by Crane:Start for all services in order of their LoadOrder and should not be called manually in most cases. If CRANE_DEBUGGING is enabled, errors are caught and logged instead of being thrown. function MyService:onInit() -- Initialization logic here print("Service initialized") end

searchDocs.title: Start​
searchDocs.content: </> Service:Start() → () Starts the service by calling the onStart callback if it exists. This method is automatically called by Crane:Start for all services after initialization and should not be called manually in most cases. If CRANE_DEBUGGING is enabled, errors are caught and logged instead of being thrown. function MyService:onStart() -- Startup logic here print("Service started") end

searchDocs.title: ComponentDef​
searchDocs.content: </> type ComponentDef = <T={any}?>{ Name: string, Tag: string?, BaseComponent: T? } Configuration table for creating a new component.

searchDocs.title: ComponentData​
searchDocs.content: </> type ComponentData = <T>ComponentDef & { instance: T, Destroying: Signal.Signal<nil>, onStart: ((self: Component<T>) → ())? } Internal data structure for component instances.

searchDocs.title: Component​
searchDocs.content: </> type Component = <T=Instance >setmetatable<ComponentData<T>,typeof(Component)> Represents a component instance in the Crane framework.

searchDocs.title: new​
searchDocs.content: </> Component:new(options: ComponentDef<T>) → Component<T> Creates a new component definition. This is typically called by Crane:CreateComponent. local component = Component.new({ Name = "MyComponent", Tag = "MyComponentTag", BaseComponent = {}, })

searchDocs.title: Instantiate​
searchDocs.content: </> Component:Instantiate(instance: T & Instance ) → Component<T> Creates a new instance of this component attached to a specific Roblox instance. This method is typically called by Crane:AddComponent and should not be called directly in most cases. local componentInstance = component:Instantiate(workspace.Part)

searchDocs.title: Destroy​
searchDocs.content: </> Component:Destroy() → () Destroys the component instance, firing the Destroying signal and cleaning up resources. component:Destroy()

searchDocs.title: Start​
searchDocs.content: </> Component:Start() → () Starts the component by calling the onStart callback if it exists. This method is automatically called by Crane:AddComponent and should not be called manually in most cases. If CRANE_DEBUGGING is enabled, errors are caught and logged instead of being thrown.

searchDocs.title: SignalConnection​
searchDocs.content: </> interface SignalConnection { Connected: boolean Disconnect: (SignalConnection) → () } Represents a connection to a signal. local connection = signal:Connect(function() end) print(connection.Connected) --> true connection:Disconnect() print(connection.Connected) --> false

searchDocs.title: ConnectionFn​
searchDocs.content: </> type ConnectionFn = (...any) → () A function connected to a signal.

searchDocs.title: new​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal.new() → Signal Constructs a new Signal

searchDocs.title: Wrap​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal.Wrap( rbxScriptSignal: RBXScriptSignal -- Existing RBXScriptSignal to wrap ) → Signal Constructs a new Signal that wraps around an RBXScriptSignal. For example: local signal = Signal.Wrap(workspace.ChildAdded) signal:Connect(function(part) print(part.Name .. " added") end) Instance.new("Part").Parent = workspace

searchDocs.title: Is​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal.Is( obj: any-- Object to check ) → boolean-- true if the object is a Signal. Checks if the given object is a Signal.

searchDocs.title: Connect​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal:Connect(fn: ConnectionFn) → SignalConnection Connects a function to the signal, which will be called anytime the signal is fired. signal:Connect(function(msg, num) print(msg, num) end) signal:Fire("Hello", 25)

searchDocs.title: Once​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal:Once(fn: ConnectionFn) → SignalConnection Connects a function to the signal, which will be called the next time the signal fires. Once the connection is triggered, it will disconnect itself. signal:Once(function(msg, num) print(msg, num) end) signal:Fire("Hello", 25) signal:Fire("This message will not go through", 10)

searchDocs.title: DisconnectAll​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal:DisconnectAll() → () Disconnects all connections from the signal. signal:DisconnectAll()

searchDocs.title: Fire​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal:Fire(...: any) → () Fire the signal, which will call all of the connected functions with the given arguments. signal:Fire("Hello") -- Any number of arguments can be fired: signal:Fire("Hello", 32, {Test = "Test"}, true)

searchDocs.title: FireDeferred​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal:FireDeferred(...: any) → () Same as Fire, but uses task.defer internally & doesn't take advantage of thread reuse. signal:FireDeferred("Hello")

searchDocs.title: Wait​
searchDocs.content: This is a yielding function. When called, it will pause the Lua thread that called the function until a result is ready to be returned, without interrupting other scripts. Yields </> Signal:Wait() → ...any Yields the current thread until the signal is fired, and returns the arguments fired from the signal. Yielding the current thread is not always desirable. If the desire is to only capture the next event fired, using Once might be a better solution. task.spawn(function() local msg, num = signal:Wait() print(msg, num) --> "Hello", 32 end) signal:Fire("Hello", 32)

searchDocs.title: Destroy​
searchDocs.content: </> Signal:Destroy() → () Cleans up the signal. Technically, this is only necessary if the signal is created usingSignal.Wrap. Connections should be properly GC'd once the signal is no longer referenced anywhere. However, it is still good practice to include ways to strictly clean up resources. Calling Destroy on a signal will also disconnect all connections immediately. signal:Destroy()

searchDocs.title: Start​
searchDocs.content: </> Crane:Start() → () Starts the framework. This method initializes all services in order, then starts them, and finally sets up automatic component tracking for tagged instances. Important: Services and components must be created before starting the framework! local Crane = require(PATH_TO_FRAMEWORK) Crane:AddServices({FOLDER, FOLDER...}) Crane:AddComponents({FOLDER, FOLDER...}) Crane:Start()

searchDocs.title: Errors
searchDocs.content: Type	DescriptionThrows an error if the framework has already been started

searchDocs.title: AddServices​
searchDocs.content: </> Crane:AddServices( parents: {Instance }, descendants: boolean? ) → {Service} Scans the provided folders/instances for ModuleScripts containing services and automatically registers them in Crane. The parameter descendants is optional and determines whether to search for services in descendants of the parent instances. Crane:AddServices({ game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage"):WaitForChild("Services"), game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage"):WaitForChild("Services"):WaitForChild("SubServices"), }) -- Search in descendants as well Crane:AddServices({ game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage"):WaitForChild("Services"), }, true)

searchDocs.title: Errors
searchDocs.content: Type	DescriptionThrows an error if parents is not a table or is empty

searchDocs.title: AddComponents​
searchDocs.content: </> Crane:AddComponents( parents: {Instance }, descendants: boolean? ) → {Component} Scans the provided folders/instances for ModuleScripts containing components and automatically registers them in Crane. The parameter descendants is optional and determines whether to search for components in descendants of the parent instances. Crane:AddComponents({ game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage"):WaitForChild("Components"), game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage"):WaitForChild("Components"):WaitForChild("SubComponents"), }) -- Search in descendants as well Crane:AddComponents({ game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage"):WaitForChild("Components"), }, true)

searchDocs.title: AddComponent​
searchDocs.content: </> Crane:AddComponent( instance: T & Instance , name: string ) → Component<T> Adds a component instance to a specific Roblox instance. This method creates a new instance of the component and attaches it to the provided instance. If the instance already has components, they will share the same component ID. local part = workspace:FindFirstChild("MyPart") local component = Crane:AddComponent(part, "MyComponent") The framework has not been started name is not a string or is empty The component does not exist The component already exists on the instance
